00035 /**
00036  *  Handles the 'start / stop' commands
00037  *  @param name: the daemon's name
00038  *  @param cmd:  the command, either 'start' or 'stop'
00039  *
00040  */
00041 DaemonErrorCode daemon_handle_command(char *name, char *cmd) {
00042 
00043         DEBUG_MSG("DEBUG: daemon_handle_command: BEGIN\n");
00044 
00045         int command = __daemon_translate_command(cmd);
00046         DaemonErrorCode command_result;
00047 
00048         switch(command) {
00049         case COMMAND_STOP:
00050                 command_result = __daemon_handle_stop(name);
00051                 break;
00052         case COMMAND_START:
00053                 command_result = __daemon_handle_start(name);
00054                 break;
00055         default:
00056                 return DAEMON_CODE_INVALID_COMMAND;
00057         }
00058 
00059         DEBUG_MSG("DEBUG: daemon_handle_command: END\n");
00060 
00061         return command_result;
00062 }// daemon_handle_command

00064 /**
00065  * Returns 0 if the command is valid
00066  */
00067 int daemon_validate_command(char *command) {
00068 
00069         int result = __daemon_translate_command(command);
00070 
00071         return !(result != COMMAND_INVALID);
00072 }

00079 /**
00080  * Handles the ``stop`` command
00081  *
00082  *  We need to determine if the daemon is running;
00083  *  this is done by inspecting the PID file as well as
00084  *  the /proc/$pid/cmdline that started the process pointed
00085  *  to in /var/run/$name
00086  *
00087  */
00088 DaemonErrorCode __daemon_handle_stop(char *name) {
00089 
00090         DEBUG_MSG("DEBUG: __daemon_handle_stop: BEGIN\n");
00091 
00092         DaemonErrorCode result;
00093         pid_t pid;
00094 
00095         // GET the PID from /var/run
00096         result =__daemon_get_pid_from_file(name, &pid);
00097         if (DAEMON_CODE_OK != result) {
00098                 return result;
00099         }
00100 
00101         // whatever happens, we need to get rid
00102         //  of stale PID file
00103         __daemon_delete_pid_file(name);
00104 
00105         // COMPARE with the command-line that should
00106         //  have started the daemon
00107         result = __daemon_verify_match(name, pid);
00108         if (DAEMON_CODE_OK != result) {
00109                 return result;
00110         }
00111 
00112         // SEND the kill signal...
00113         int kill_result = kill( pid, SIGTERM);
00114 
00115         if (0!=kill_result) {
00116                 return DAEMON_CODE_KILL_FAILED;
00117         }
00118 
00119         doLog(LOG_INFO, "daemon stopped, pid[%u]", pid);
00120 
00121         DEBUG_MSG("DEBUG: __daemon_handle_stop: END\n");
00122 
00123         return DAEMON_CODE_EXITING;
00124 } // STOP

00126 /**
00127  * Handles the ``start`` command
00128  *
00129  *  The daemon must not already exist (!)
00130  */
00131 DaemonErrorCode __daemon_handle_start(char *name) {
00132 
00133         DEBUG_MSG("DEBUG: __daemon_handle_start: BEGIN\n");
00134 
00135         DaemonErrorCode result;
00136         pid_t pid;
00137 
00138         // GET the PID from /var/run
00139         result =__daemon_get_pid_from_file(name, &pid);
00140         if (DAEMON_CODE_OK == result) {
00141 
00142                 // we got a PID... is the daemon really running?
00143                 result = __daemon_verify_match(name, pid);
00144                 if (DAEMON_CODE_OK == result) {
00145                         return DAEMON_CODE_DAEMON_EXIST;
00146                 }
00147 
00148                 //get rid of stale PID file
00149                 __daemon_delete_pid_file(name);
00150                 DEBUG_MSG("DEBUG: __daemon_handle_start: got rid of stale PID file\n");
00151         }
00152 
00153         DEBUG_MSG("DEBUG: __daemon_handle_start: BEFORE daemon()\n");
00154         // DEMON START
00155         daemon(0,0);
00156 
00157         result = __daemon_write_pid_file(name);
00158 
00159         doLog(LOG_INFO, "daemon started" );
00160 
00161         return result;
00162 }// START

00167 DaemonErrorCode __daemon_write_pid_file(char *name) {
00168 
00169         DEBUG_MSG("DEBUG: __daemon_write_pid_file: BEGIN\n");
00170 
00171         char *filename;
00172         pid_t pid = getpid();
00173         FILE *file;
00174         char write_buffer[32];
00175 
00176         filename = __daemon_construct_pid_filename(name);
00177 
00178         file = fopen(filename, "w");
00179         if (NULL==file) {
00180                 return DAEMON_CODE_WRITING_PID_FILE;
00181         }
00182 
00183         free(filename);
00184 
00185         snprintf(write_buffer, 31, "%u", pid);
00186 
00187         if (EOF==fputs((const char *)write_buffer, file)) {
00188                 fclose(file);
00189                 return DAEMON_CODE_WRITING_PID_FILE;
00190         }
00191         fclose(file);
00192 
00193         DEBUG_MSG("DEBUG: __daemon_write_pid_file: END\n");
00194 
00195         return DAEMON_CODE_OK;
00196 }// __daemon_write_pid_file

00214 /**
00215  * Translates a string command to an integer
00216  *  whilst verifying the validity of the said command.
00217  *
00218  */
00219 int __daemon_translate_command(char *cmd) {
00220 
00221         if (NULL==cmd) {
00222                 return COMMAND_INVALID;
00223         }
00224 
00225         if (0==strncasecmp(cmd, "start", sizeof("start"))) {
00226                 return COMMAND_START;
00227         }
00228 
00229         if (0==strncasecmp(cmd, "stop", sizeof("stop"))) {
00230                 return COMMAND_STOP;
00231         }
00232 
00233         return COMMAND_INVALID;
00234 }// __daemon_translate_command

00237  * Returns 1 if TRUE

00239 int daemon_is_start_command(char *command) {
00240

00315 /**
00316  * Verifies that the process of PID $pid matches
00317  *  the command line $name.
00318  *
00319  *  If there isn't a match, it is probably because:
00320  *  1) the daemon is non-existent / killed
00321  *  2) the command-line that started the daemon isn't what
00322  *     it is expected... renamed probably?
00323  *
00324  *  This function reads the command-line string found
00325  *  in /proc/$pid/cmdline and matches it with $name
00326  *
00327  */
00328 DaemonErrorCode __daemon_verify_match(char *name, pid_t pid) {
00329 
00330         DEBUG_MSG("DEBUG: __daemon_verify_match: BEGIN\n");
00331 
00332         char filename[1024];
00333         char read_buffer[1024];
00334         FILE *file;
00335         int  rc;
00336         regex_t * myregex = calloc(1, sizeof(regex_t));
00337 
00338 
00339         if (NULL==name) {
00340                 return DAEMON_CODE_INVALID_NAME;
00341         }
00342 
00343         if (0==pid) {
00344                 return DAEMON_CODE_INVALID_PID;
00345         }
00346 
00347         snprintf(filename, sizeof(filename)*sizeof(char), "/proc/%u/cmdline", pid);
00348         DEBUG_LOG(LOG_DEBUG, "process cmdline filename [%s]", filename);
00349 
00350         file = fopen( filename, "r" );
00351         if (NULL==file) {
00352                 return DAEMON_CODE_READING_PROC_CMDLINE;
00353         }
00354 
00355         char *result = \
00356                 fgets(read_buffer, sizeof(read_buffer)*sizeof(char), file );
00357 
00358         fclose( file );
00359 
00360         if (result!=read_buffer) {
00361                 return DAEMON_CODE_READING_PROC_CMDLINE;
00362         }
00363 
00364         // perform sub-string match test
00365         rc = regcomp( myregex, name, REG_EXTENDED | REG_NOSUB );
00366         if (0!=rc) {
00367                 // if we have trouble compiling the regex,
00368                 //  then the daemon name is not appropriate;
00369                 //  anyhow, the daemon name SHOULD be simple!
00370                 return DAEMON_CODE_INVALID_NAME;
00371         }
00372 
00373         rc = regexec( myregex, read_buffer, 0, 0, 0 );
00374         if (0!=rc) {
00375                 return DAEMON_CODE_PROC_CMDLINE_NOMATCH;
00376         }
00377 
00378         DEBUG_MSG("DEBUG: __daemon_verify_match: END\n");
00379 
00380         return DAEMON_CODE_OK;
00381 }// daemon_verify_match
